name: sfchronicle
text: SF author Dave Eggers curates benefit album of indie rock rarities, available for 24 hours only. Story by @MusicSF: https://t.co/A4DMBOIL8v

name: sfchronicle
text:
SFPD officers and other city employees have been able to use a dozen gyms during the pandemic, mostly inside police stations, despite the fact that private gyms have been closed to the public for the past several months.

Story by @TrishaThadani: https://t.co/dHfC6ODaoB

name: sfchronicle
text: Pac-12 said it has partnered with a diagnostic test company to establish daily rapid-results coronavirus testing of student-athletes across its campuses, a "major step toward the safe resumption of Pac-12 sport," commissioner Larry Scott said. https://t.co/54zlBOh4wX

name: sfchronicle
text: Though the last 40 seconds of her grandson’s life have been seen widely, Addie Kitchen said she wants #StevenTaylor to be known for who he was during the rest of his 33 years — a lovable goofball and aspiring rapper with 3 kids and a large extended family. https://t.co/xNhSioRLgX

name: sfchronicle
text: One of the Bay Area’s popular new pandemic-born food pop-ups has been shut down by Alameda County’s health department after “a neighbor” reported her illegal operation. Is tolerance for these pop-up operations waning? https://t.co/4Ildmb7Dgj

name: sfchronicle
text: Megafires sparked last month constitute three of the top four largest wildfires in modern state history. The SCU Lightning Complex (391,578 acres) is No. 2. The LNU Lightning Complex (375,209 acres) is No. 3. The August Complex (287,106 acres) is No. 4. https://t.co/N2KH0zkQ4t

name: sfchronicle
text: From @JustMrPhillips: While white people have the choice of opting out of the country’s racial awakening, it’s worth remembering that Black suffering drives Black activism, which is why we’re seeing so much of it. https://t.co/SUICwwQLh9

name: sfchronicle
text: Complimentary tickets to the advance screening of ‘All In: The Fight for Democracy’ at the West Wind Capitol Drive-In are available to Chronicle Members for Wednesday, September 9, 2020. Click here for more information: https://t.co/92xWL82Kwe

name: sfchronicle
text: It was front-page news when incumbent President Ronald Reagan kicked off his fall re-election campaign on Sept. 3, 1984, with a Labor Day rally at De Anza College in Cupertino. https://t.co/WT6DAxRerH

text: Here’s an update on conditions at popular destinations across the Bay Area and Northern California. https://t.co/CSyqVmQ7SP

text:

text:
Like Santa Rosa and Paradise before it, the small community in the Santa Cruz Mountains is trying to figure out whether its water system was contaminated by wildfire.
https://t.co/Ahn5nQaNrg

name: sfchronicle
text:
The blazes sparked last month and still burning in Northern California now constitute three of the top four largest wildfires in modern state history, Cal Fire reports. Follow our live updates for the latest: 
https://t.co/gw5zK8I3Q7

name: sfchronicle
text:
The Chabot Science and Space Center is auctioning off a personal planetarium show as part of its effort to make up some of its losses from the pandemic, marketing a romantic dinner for two under the stars.
https://t.co/B1nTQw3w5X

name: sfchronicle
text: Welcome to entertaining in 2020. Your typical gathering or backyard BBQ likely looks much different today than it did last summer — if it happens at all. https://t.co/futxyz4J2S

text:

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @demianbulwa: "Erica Chavis cried as she watched her son, Laney wide receiver Dior Scott, crawl into the backseat of his SUV to sleep. She hadn’t known until she saw Netflix’s 'Last Chance U' that Scott was homeless for much of his sophomore season."

Via @Con_Chron https://t.co/QppvirXXxy

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @lisagartner: Two horses galloped toward them at full speed, their eyelids peeled back in panic. The larger crashed into his pickup. The smaller horse thumped into his daughter-in-law’s vehicle.

“We kept going,” he said. “We had to keep going.” @mgafni @lizziejohnsonnn https://t.co/CDZ7UUA3l1

name: sfchronicle
text: The No. 1 spot is still held by 2018’s Mendocino Complex fire, which left 459,123 acres burned. https://t.co/IsEXbeMiWq

name: sfchronicle
text:
California’s wildfire season started with a roar this year — and we’re only just approaching the critical months of October and November.

How much worse will it get? https://t.co/rfAEsOyPdG

text:

name: sfchronicle
text:
San Francisco recorded another 59 coronavirus cases for a total of 9,755 cases on Friday. San Mateo County confirmed another 62 cases, bringing its total to 8,452. Follow our live updates for the latest:
https://t.co/JocRFdqpg8

name: sfchronicle
text: Experts say the outlook for the critical wildfire season months is not good in Northern California, already ravaged by lightning-sparked blazes. Data show that the meager rainy season, heat waves and Diablo winds could be a recipe for disaster. https://t.co/ZwTUPtFZ5C

name: sfchronicle
text: Triple-digit temperatures are expected to bake the Bay Area over the Labor Day holiday, with an excessive heat warning this weekend followed by a fire weather watch early next week. https://t.co/Qt7KIIyBLX

name: sfchronicle
text: At Volker Eisele Family Estate in Napa’s remote Chiles Valley, some of the region’s oldest Cabernet Sauvignon vines burned in the Hennessey Fire, but somehow the 150-year-old historic winery survived. https://t.co/vRpPQFdWLV

name: sfchronicle
text: “I want people not to forget. In my heart, I hope and pray that nobody will have to go through this. But I know it’s still happening. … So my gut feeling is: When is it going to stop? What do we have to do to get this to stop?” https://t.co/KM2oWWdtyD

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @MusicSF: Billed as Fort Mason Flix, the pop-up theater on the northern waterfront of the city will host films six days a week through Oct. 18.

The initial offerings include “The Matrix,” “Xanadu,” “Frozen,” “Purple Rain” and “The Big Lebowski.”

https://t.co/dR2KMhKow7

name: sfchronicle
text: San Francisco is set to get its first pandemic drive-in theater at the Fort Mason Center for Arts & Culture on Sept. 18. https://t.co/AvsWKl1OzM

name: sfchronicle
text: A heat wave is descending on Northern California this Labor Day weekend. Temperatures could reach triple digits in some areas. To help beat the heat, cooling centers will open with safeguards to reduce exposure and spread of COVID-19. https://t.co/3PLRDl8boU

name: sfchronicle
text: IKEA’s parent company has purchased San Francisco’s long-vacant 6X6 shopping center, in a rare sign of retail expansion in San Francisco's struggling Mid-Market district. https://t.co/6ujtjbtmds
